page.title: 04USES OF THE WORFE
page.content: Originally the tributary brooks and the Worfe itself provided a source of power for numerous mills along their banks.The flow was dammed to provide sufficient head of water.In a 2 mile stretch of the Albrighton Brook 4 mills combined with several windmills to serve the needs of local farmers.A mill at Cosford was pulled down in 1969 and a large house built. On the Ruckley Brook a bone grinding mill was sited on the site of the present railway bridge.It was pulled down because of complaints about the smell. The other use for the River Worfe besides supplying Wolverhampton with water was to supply the G.W.R. which had a pumping station and borehole at its crossing of the Neachley Brook in order to supply trains en-route from Holyhead to London.
